awd_abstract_narration:
Shipboard Scientific Support Equipment (SSSE) is requested to support operations by the West Coast Van Pool (WCVP). The Pool currently consists of 15 modular laboratory vans that are all owned by either by NSF or Oregon State University. The pool is managed by Oregon State University and portable research vans are shipped all over the world in support of sea-going science. The Van Pool supports scientific operations and data collection aboard National Science Foundation (NSF) supported research vessels by supplying required additional specialized portable laboratory space and associated instrumentation. This proposal seeks SSSE for the following equipment:

Replacement LSCs for West Coast Van Pool Isotope Portable Laboratory	$78,700
Water bag for load testing overboarding equipment	$18,332
						$97,032
Broader Impacts		
The principal impact of the present proposal is under Merit Review Criterion 2 of the Proposal Guidelines (NSF 19-602). It provides infrastructure support for scientists to use the vessel and its shared-use instrumentation in support of their NSF-funded oceanographic research projects (which individually undergo separate review by the relevant research program of NSF).  The acquisition, maintenance and operation of shared-use instrumentation allows NSF-funded researchers from any US university or lab access to working, calibrated instruments for their research, reducing the cost of that research, and expanding the base of potential researchers.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The 2021 Shipboard Scientific Support Equipment grant was for two Hidex LSC’s for the West Coast Van Pool and a 12 ton water bag for the R/V Oceanus and R/V Taani. At time of submission for the request, the West Coast Van Pool had two Isotope Vans with aging and obsolete Beckman-Coulter LSC units that were increasingly difficult to service and repair. Without replacement units, the old models would become impossible to service and therefore would become unusable for the scientific community. The Hidex units were decided due to the updates in technology that allowed for liquid scintillation counting without a live source as well as recommendations from Woods Hole for the Hidex units’ efficiency and intuitive use for the seagoing scientific community. Additionally, previous to the SSSE award, the R/V Oceanus did not have a waterbag to use for load testing overboard handling systems and relied on rentals or borrowing from other operations. The operation owning its own waterbag allows for reliable and regular load testing of ship systems on the Oceanus as well as the Taani.

Upon receiving the SSSE award for the LSCs and the waterbag, orders were placed for the proposed equipment mid-May of 2021. The equipment was received in late summer of 2021. At the time of reception for the Hidex LSC units, most of the Portable Isotope Laboratories were in the field and were not available for installation. Once the portable laboratories arrived back in Newport for the winter, the units were scheduled for installation. Both units have been installed in Portable Isotope Laboratories R-3 and R-5 and three members of OSU Ship Operations have received familiarization training on the Hidex units. In May 2022, R-3 was deployed in support of the OA-Fe Availability project under the direction of Dr. Mark Wells aboard the R/V Sikuliaq, and is the first project of the year to use a new Hidex LSC in a West Coast Portable Laboratory. OSU Ship Operations received the waterbag and associated equipment by the end of July, 2021. In the summer of 2021 R/V Oceanus unfortunately suffered a broken seal on the vessel’s main crane cylinder. Although a less than ideal circumstance, by the time the cylinder was repaired and ready to be reinstalled on the vessel, load testing was required which offered an opportunity to use the new waterbag for the vessel. Load testing went well and the equipment was much more preferable to other past rentals and borrowed equipment due to its ease of use and allowance for more control in the amount of water added to or removed from the waterbag in addition to the use of the calibrated load cells for the equipment. The waterbag by the time the order was placed did have a few pricing updates, particularly to the waterbag itself, the 25 Te Tension Load Cell, and the total shipping costs.


Last Modified: 06/08/2022
Modified by: Kaya Johnson

The 2021 Shipboard Scientific Support Equipment grant was for two Hidex LSC’s for the West  Coast Van Pool and a 12 ton water bag for the R/V Oceanus and R/V Taani.  At time of submission for the request, the West Coast Van Pool had two Isotope Vans with aging  and obsolete Beckman-Coulter LSC units that were increasingly difficult to service and repair.  Without replacement units, the old models would become impossible to service and therefore  would become unusable for the scientific community. The Hidex units were decided due to the  updates in technology that allowed for liquid scintillation counting without a live source as well  as recommendations from Woods Hole for the Hidex units’ efficiency and intuitive use for the  seagoing scientific community. Additionally, previous to the SSSE award, the R/V Oceanus did not have a waterbag to use for  load testing overboard handling systems and relied on rentals or borrowing from other  operations. The operation owning its own waterbag allows for reliable and regular load testing of  ship systems on the Oceanus as well as the Taani.

Upon receiving the SSSE award for the LSCs and the waterbag, orders were placed for the  proposed equipment mid-May of 2021. The equipment was received in late summer of 2021.  At the time of reception for the Hidex LSC units, most of the Portable Isotope Laboratories were  in the field and were not available for installation. Once the portable laboratories arrived back in  Newport for the winter, the units were scheduled for installation. Both units have been installed  in Portable Isotope Laboratories R-3 and R-5 and three members of OSU Ship Operations have  received familiarization training on the Hidex units. In May 2022, R-3 was deployed in support  of the OA-Fe Availability project under the direction of Dr. Mark Wells aboard the R/V Sikuliaq,  and is the first project of the year to use a new Hidex LSC in a West Coast Portable Laboratory. OSU Ship Operations received the waterbag and associated equipment by the end of July, 2021.  In the summer of 2021 R/V Oceanus unfortunately suffered a broken seal on the vessel’s main  crane cylinder. Although a less than ideal circumstance, by the time the cylinder was repaired  and ready to be reinstalled on the vessel, load testing was required which offered an opportunity  to use the new waterbag for the vessel. Load testing went well and the equipment was much  more preferable to other past rentals and borrowed equipment due to its ease of use and  allowance for more control in the amount of water added to or removed from the waterbag in  addition to the use of the calibrated load cells for the equipment. The waterbag by the time the order was placed did have a few pricing updates, particularly to the waterbag itself, the 25 Te Tension Load Cell, and the total shipping costs.
